newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Coles' Eck may be paid less - Clark.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Coles' Eck may be paid less - Clark.

text.p: Coles Myer Ltd's new managing director and chief executive officer (CEO) Dennis Eck may be paid less than outgoing CEO Peter Bartels, Coles Myer chairman Nobby Clark said on Tuesday.

Asked in an interview on Australian Broadcasting Corp radio if Eck's pay would be comparable to Bartels', Clark said: "I'm not sure that it will be, but that's a matter for disclosure at the appropriate time and in the appropriate form."

"Mr Eck, you will find, when you look at the structure of the company will be doing a different job to Mr Bartels, in a different way with a different management team and what we pay him will be reasonable and appropriate," Clark said.
Bartels resigned late on Monday as Coles Myer's managing director and CEO and is to be replaced by Eck from January 1.

Bartels had been under pressure through 1996 due to the group's financial performance. The disclosure of his A$2.8 million 1995/96 pay package further enraged Coles shareholders at the company's annual meeting last month.
Coles' shares closed up three cents at A$4.52 on Monday.
New Zealand's Brierley Investments Ltd owns 6.8 percent of Coles.
